description.narrative: The Output is created for the development and implementation of Disaster Risk Reduction Program

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1.1. Organize consultations with relevant agencies at the country level to integrate preparedness programmes and drills into the annual school curriculum. 1.2. Support the schools in reviewing their preparedness plans, drill scenarios, Standard Operating Procedures and evacuation routes and ensure all relevant materials and tools are available in local language as required. 1.3. Evaluate the drills organized by the schools on a designated annual day. 1.4. Drive commitments by local governments to cost-share and allocate annual resources for school preparedness activities. 1.5. Continue to feature project activities on the microsite including events around World Tsunami Awareness Day. 1.6 Support activities around Tonga Rock. 2.1. Develop new partnerships with local governments, private sector, academic institutions, media agencies and local communities that substantially help to scale up the preparedness programmes and drills in countries. 2.2. Organize Training of Trainers for schools. 2.3. Support the further development of STEP A for universal applicability in multiple countries and for multiple hazards 2.4. Support five new countries in Asia-Pacific to organize preparedness programmes and drills based on lessons learnt and good practice guidelines under phase 1. 2.5. Produce stories, blogs and videos featuring the drills on the project microsite and promote on social media. 3.1. Deploy experts to countries requiring support on data collection.

115 tsunami-prone schools in 18 tsunami prone countries in Asia-Pacific developed preparedness plans and tested safe evacuation through the conduct of drills under a Government of Japan funded regional project. Over 60,000 students, teachers and school administration directly benefitted. Collaboration and partnerships at various levels contributed to the successful implementation of the project i.e. collaboration between UNDP COs, JICA, NDMOs, MOE and NGOs like the Red Cross, Save the Children etc. Robust communications and a highly visible social media presence in English, Japanese and local language contributed to high visual impact of the project. Results were presented at high level events commemorating World Tsunami Awareness Day 2018 and additional funds were mobilised from the Government of Japan to support another phase of the project.
A study analysying the impact of disasters on the road sector in Cambodia, Lao PDR and Myanmar was completed with the aim of influencing public sector investments and planning to include DRR measures.

Over 100,000 students, teachers and school administration trained in tsunami education and safe evacuation drills, raising the total to 150,000 from 23 countries across two phases of the regional tsunami project. Key results in 2020 included: five countries institutionalized annual school tsunami preparedness; two local governments committed to cost-share tsunami preparedness activities; 24 videos, 4 newsletters and articles promoted visibility and awareness of tsunami preparedness efforts and World Tsunami Awareness Day promoted at high level events. In collaboration with UNDRR, a checklist for school administrators on tsunami evacuation during COVID-19 was developed based on lessons learned from Japan.

Under the second phase of the Government of Japan funded regional project, 23 countries engaged with their national government counterparts to implement and scale up school preparedness to tsunamis. Specifically, 203 tsunami-prone schools in 11 countries developed or reviewed and updated preparedness plans and tested safe evacuation drills involving over 70,000 students, teachers and school administration. Nine countries held Training of Trainer (TOTs) to scale up in more schools and some developed a TOT module in their local language. A Regional Guide for Schools to Prepare for Tsunamis was completed and disseminated and some countries used the guide to develop a national guide in local language in response to Government request (e.g. Sri Lanka and Thailand). A key result of efforts at institutionalizing drills is in Palau where the Presidential Proclamation 19-269 marks September as the preparedness month and all schools are expected to conduct evacuation drills annually. (Presidential Proclamation to be attached). Partnerships at the country level with focal Government Ministries, NGOs and the Japan embassy were strengthened through project implementation activities. On the occasion of the Rugby World Cup 2019, a new partnership was established with Kamaishi city of Japan. A collaboration video produced in Japanese and English was screened in Kamaishi city advocating the importance of preparedness and featuring players from Japan and Fiji. The project’s new campaign #PrepareToWin was launched and high visibility events were promoted on social media. To mark World Tsunami Awareness Day 2019, UNDP and UNDRR partnered and produced a video on how preparedness and resilient infrastructure can save lives, in line with the Sendai Framework Target D which was the theme for the WTAD. The video was screened at the high-level event in New York and disseminated on social media.
